newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian silver bounds higher, reflects overseas.
newsitem.headline: Indian silver bounds higher, reflects overseas.

text.p: Silver prices shot up sharply from early lows in response to stronger prices overseas and low supplies, dealers said.
Prices for silver.999 were quoted at 7,240 rupees per kg, gaining 165 rupees from Wednesday's close of 7,075.
Silver .916 was up 175 rupees at 7,150, compared to 6,975 on Wednesday.
Silver prices had fallen around 80 rupees per kg on Wednesday. The buoyancy of world markets and some phusical shortage prompted a recovery, but dealers said physcial buying remained low.
Silver prices jumped up from 4.83/4.84 dollars to 5.12/5.13 dollars per ounce in the world market.
Gold prices in the local market also bounced back from the lower level on the back of smart recovery in the world market.
Twenty-four carat gold was quoted at 4,780 rupees per 10 gms, gaining 25 rupees from Wednesday's close of 4,755.
Twenty-two carat gold was 4,420 rupees, up 20 from Wednesday's close.
Gold fell around 30 rupees per 10 gramme on Wednesday.
Prices of a gold biscuit (116.50 gramme) rose by 300 rupees to 55,900 rupees per piece in the early trade today. They were down by 300 rupees per piece on Wednesday.
In the world market gold prices moved up from $336/337 to $344/345 per ounce. Overall sentiment was firm in early trade but some traders expected light profit-taking.
